channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine Wants New Powerful Weapons From the U.S. Biden Is Not So Sure.
item.description: President Biden wants to avoid provoking Russia at a moment when American officials fear Vladimir V. Putin could escalate the war to compensate for recent losses.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Anton Troianovski, Julian E. Barnes and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: While supporting Ukraine against Russian aggression, President Biden has tried to prevent the conflict from widening.

item.title: Ukraine’s Donbas, Where Putin Sowed the Seeds of War
item.description: In one small town in the Donbas region, everything suddenly fell apart. It was part of Vladimir Putin’s grand plan, and it helped lay the groundwork for the invasion of Ukraine. Now things are heating up again.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: A road outside Chasiv Yar with mountains of slag visible on the horizon.

item.title: Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Plant Has Power Restored, Watchdog Says
item.description: Maintaining power at Europe’s largest nuclear plant has been crucial to prevent a meltdown in the shadow of fighting nearby.
item.dc:creator: Ben Shpigel
item.media:description: A motorcade transporting experts with the International Atomic Energy Agency arrived at the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant outside the Russian-controlled city of Enerhodar, Ukraine.

item.title: ‘A Crisis Coming’: The Twin Threats to American Democracy
item.description: The United States faces two distinct challenges, the movement by Republicans who refuse to accept defeat in an election and a growing disconnect between political power and public opinion.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt

item.title: The U.S. Vowed to Defend Central American Democracy. Autocrats Had Other Plans.
item.description: The Biden administration’s plan to stem migration by building the rule of law in Central America has thus far failed to stop authoritarians or persuade people to stay.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Jody García
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Daniele Volpe for The New York Times
item.media:description: A protest outside the Guatemalan Parliament against corruption and the persecution of independent judges and journalists last month in Guatemala City.

item.title: Migrants Flown to Martha’s Vineyard by DeSantis Say They Were Misled
item.description: The flights, arranged by Florida’s Republican governor, underscored how easily the fate of immigrants can be swept up in politics.
item.dc:creator: Remy Tumin and Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Matt Cosby for The New York Times

item.title: Justice Dept. Appeals Part of Special Master Review in Trump Case
item.description: The government, while calling a lower court’s decision “unprecedented,” did not seek to stop the installation of an outside arbiter to review other materials taken from Mar-a-Lago.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush, Alan Feuer and Charlie Savage
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: The filing sets up a clash between the Justice Department, pictured above, and former President Donald J. Trump at the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit, in Atlanta.

item.title: As Trump Inquiry Heats Up, Garland Warns of Threats to Rule of Law
item.description: Addressing new citizens on Ellis Island, the attorney general emphasized that all Americans are equal under the law.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush
item.media:description: Attorney General Merrick B. Garland speaks at a naturalization ceremony at Ellis Island in New York on Saturday.

item.title: Rally With Trump? Some G.O.P. Candidates Aren’t Thrilled About It.
item.description: Whether he is invited or not, the former president keeps holding rallies in battleground states. It reflects an awkward dance as Republican candidates try to win over general-election voters.
item.dc:creator: Michael C. Bender and Maggie Haberman
item.media:credit: Hannah Beier for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former President Donald J. Trump held a rally in Wilkes-Barre, Pa., after his aides told the campaign of Dr. Mehmet Oz, the Republican nominee for Senate, that Mr. Trump wanted to hold an event in the state.

item.title: Republicans on the Defensive on Abortion and Other Social Issues
item.description: Republican missteps have helped to spotlight the party’s divisions on abortion and same-sex marriage, two issues on which their base is out of step with the general public.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:credit: Shuran Huang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Most Americans favor abortion rights, but many Republican voters want strict abortion limits if not an outright ban.

item.title: Meghan Markle and Prince Harry’s U.K. Trip Under Scrutiny
item.description: The actions of Meghan, and her husband, Prince Harry, as they mourn the queen have been the subject of biting social commentary — as usual.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Lyall
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Meghan, the Duchess of Sussex, with Prince Harry, her husband, behind Prince William and Catherine, the Princess of Wales, viewing flowers last Saturday that were left for Queen Elizabeth II.

item.title: Prince William and Prince Harry Stood Vigil Over the Queen at Westminster Hall
item.description: Prince William and Prince Harry stood vigil over their grandmother, Queen Elizabeth II, at Westminster Hall as mourners streamed in to pay their respects.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: The line to see Queen Elizabeth II lying in state at Westminster Hall stretched for miles along the south bank of the Thames on Saturday in London.

item.title: ‘M*A*S*H’ at 50: War Is Hell(arious)
item.description: Five decades ago, “M*A*S*H” anticipated today’s TV dramedies, showing that a great comedy could be more than just funny.
item.dc:creator: James Poniewozik
item.media:description: “M*A*S*H” shows its age in various ways, including in a subplot in which Farr’s Klinger sought discharge from the Army by dressing in women’s clothes.

item.title: Alan Alda on ‘M*A*S*H’: ‘Everybody Had Something Taken From Them’
item.description: As the acclaimed “situation tragedy” turns 50, the star reflects on its innovations: “The crazy behavior wasn’t just to be funny. It was a way of separating yourself for a moment from the nastiness.”
item.dc:creator: Saul Austerlitz
item.media:description: Alan Alda starred in more than 250 episodes of “M*A*S*H,” which debuted on CBS on Sept. 17, 1972.

item.title: The Spirit Behind High-End Tequila
item.description: As the founder of Casa Dragones tequila, Bertha González Nieves is a leader in an industry still dominated by men.
item.dc:creator: Thessaly La Force
item.media:credit: Koral Carballo for The New York Times
item.media:description: “With tequila, there is actually so much sophistication,” said Bertha González Nieves, the Mexican businesswoman behind Casa Dragones tequila, sitting in front of the renovated Casa Dragones in San Miguel de Allende, Guanajuato, Mexico. “It’s an extraordinary plant. It has power. In Latin, agave means illustrious, admirable and noble.”

item.title: How Low Can Republicans Go?
item.description: G.O.P. grapes of wrath at Martha’s Vineyard.
item.dc:creator: Maureen Dowd
item.media:description: A young man who was part of a group of migrants flown to Martha's Vineyard at the Florida governor’s direction.

item.title: New York Has an Obligation to Secure the Education of Hasidic Children
item.description: Politicians have known for years about the crisis facing New York’s Hasidic schools but failed to act in any meaningful way.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board

item.title: When Diversity Isn’t the Right Kind of Diversity
item.description: No member of Liz Truss’s cabinet is a white man. Why isn’t that considered progress?
item.dc:creator: Pamela Paul
item.media:description: Suella Braverman, Britain’s new home secretary, at 10 Downing Street.

item.title: Why Queen Elizabeth’s Strength Is Putin’s Weakness
item.description: Why the mystical quality we call legitimacy is key for rulers.
item.dc:creator: Ross Douthat
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: What the Martha’s Vineyard Stunt Says About the Trump Wannabes
item.description: Is Ron DeSantis really ready for prime time?
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times

item.title: When Your Dog Is a Teenager
item.description: As at so many times during early life with dogs, patience is due. It is just a phase.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Horowitz

item.title: A Sneaky Form of Climate Obstruction Hurts Pension Funds
item.description: Some state officials are putting their political views before the best interests of the firefighters and teachers they serve.
item.dc:creator: Tobias Read
item.media:credit: George Etheredge for The New York Times
item.media:description: The facade of Goldman Sachs’ Manhattan headquarters. Some Republican state treasurers are refusing to do business with the firm because it is reducing investments in fossil fuels.

item.title: DeSantis’s Martha’s Vineyard Migrants Stunt Shows the Asylum System Is Broken
item.description: America’s immigration system has long been overburdened and outdated.
item.dc:creator: Farah Stockman

item.title: Why Things May Really Be Different for This Midterm Election
item.description: This cycle, the arguments for Democratic strength cut against the conventional wisdom that the party in power struggles in midterms.
item.dc:creator: Nate Cohn

item.title: Andrew Sean Greer on Writing ‘Less’
item.description: The novelist discusses his Pulitzer-winning comedy about the travels and travails of a heartbroken writer, and William Finnegan talks about surfing.

item.title: NYC Pizza Guide: the Best Clam Pie, Brooklyn Openings and More
item.description: The most important pizza goings-on across New York City.
item.dc:creator: Nikita Richardson

item.title: What Did You Wear to That Wedding?
item.description: Were you invited to a wedding with a nontraditional dress code (think: desert chic or coastal glam)? We want to see what you wore.
item.dc:creator: Emma Grillo
item.media:credit: Roger Kisby for The New York Times

item.title: Nancy Pelosi Visits Armenia Amid Conflict With Azerbaijan
item.description: The House speaker, who has previously inserted herself at the center of global conflicts, is the highest-ranking American official to visit Armenia since it gained independence 30 years ago.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:description: In a photo provided by the Armenian government, Speaker Nancy Pelosi was greeted by Alen Simonyan, the president of the National Assembly, on Saturday outside Yerevan, Armenia’s capital.

item.title: What’s Behind the Success of the Far-Right Sweden Democrats?
item.description: Campaigning on issues like immigration, religion, crime and the cost of environmental rules, the Sweden Democrats, a party with neo-Nazi roots, grew its support.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Christina Anderson
item.media:description: A campaign poster for the Sweden Democrats with the slogan, “Sweden Will Be Great Again,” on a bus stop in Stockholm last month.

item.title: Abortion Helps Realign Puerto Rico’s Politics
item.description: Long-dominant political parties are losing power to new ones, including one trying to limit abortion in one of the few U.S. jurisdictions where it remains unrestricted.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei
item.media:credit: Erika P. Rodriguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A panel of doctors and health experts defending abortion rights at a hearing this month on the island.

item.title: After 75 Years, Cheetahs Return to India in a Grand Experiment
item.description: Scientists aim to determine whether a predator population can be restored in a place where it was hunted into extinction.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schmall and Hari Kumar
item.media:description: A cheetah and her two grown cubs in Namibia at a Cheetah Conservation Fund enclosure. The organization is a main partner in the relocation of eight cheetahs to India this weekend.

item.title: How to Prepare for Flu Season
item.description: We may be more susceptible to the virus than we have been in recent years, but doctors have tips to stay healthy.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer

item.title: How to Nurse a Vulnerability Hangover
item.description: That thing you shared last night? It’s probably just fine.
item.dc:creator: Holly Burns

item.title: What Parents Should Know About Enterovirus: Symptoms and Risks
item.description: The C.D.C. has issued an alert about enterovirus D68, which has been linked to rare, polio-like paralysis.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Pearson
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Kayana Szymczak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Children who experience paralysis after contracting enterovirus, like this 4-year-old boy, may need physical therapy to help rebuild strength and balance.

item.title: How Family and Friends Helped Get Me Through the Pandemic
item.description: As Covid raged, many Americans hunkered down with family members and relied on friends — and some came away with deepened relationships. Here are a few of their stories.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Needelman
item.media:credit: Cig Harvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rita and Jon Ellis at Lermond Pond in Maine. Mr. Ellis credits his wife for his recovery from pancreatic cancer. They are two of the many people who leaned on family and friends to help them through a difficult couple of years.

item.title: Are monkeypox scars permanent?
item.description: The best time to care for skin lesions is in their active phase.
item.dc:creator: Knvul Sheikh

item.title: R. Crumb Means Some Offense
item.description: Even from his refuge in France, the comics artist still makes America’s pulse race.
item.dc:creator: M.H. Miller and Thibault Montamat
